channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Editorial: Tensions Rise in the South China Sea
item.description: China’s neighbors are supported by the United States in opposing Beijing’s bullying tactics over territorial claims.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Japanese destroyers and a submarine docked at a port in the Philippines near disputed South China Sea waters.

item.title: Dutch Voters Reject European Union’s Trade Deal With Ukraine
item.description: In a nonbinding referendum, voters said no to a trade and cooperation pact. All 28 member countries must approve the deal.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: To Discourage Prostitution, France Passes Bill That Penalizes Clients
item.description: First-time offenders will pay a fine of about $1,700 if they “solicit, accept or obtain relations of a sexual nature.” The fine can rise to about $4,300 for repeat offenders.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Iran Plans Visit to Rival Saudis to Discuss Hajj Pilgrimage
item.description: It would be a rare official meeting between Iran and Saudi Arabia, which broke relations in January after protesters burned the Saudi Embassy in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Bodies were gathered in Mina, Saudi Arabia, near Mecca, after a stampede in September killed hundreds of Muslim pilgrims.

item.title: Executions Highest in 25 Years, Amnesty International Says
item.description: At least 1,634 people were executed in 2015, the group found, an increase of more than 50 percent over 2014 and the highest since 1989.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Facebook Groups Act as Weapons Bazaars for Militias
item.description: Facebook posts suggest evidence of large-scale efforts to buy and sell weapons as large as guided missiles in the Middle East and North Africa.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: An account on Facebook uploaded a picture with text that read “Libya Weapons Market.”

item.title: Jacob Zuma, Under Siege, Finds Political Refuge in Rural South Africa
item.description: As urban South Africans call for his resignation, the president remains popular in the villages and towns that are his party’s stronghold.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Sbusisiwe Magwaza/Government Communication & Info System, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa, right, visiting Melmoth, a small town in the country’s southeast, on Sunday.

item.title: Conjoined Twins, a Trip to Saudi Arabia and a Risky Operation
item.description: “I still have doubts, and I am scared,” said the father of two Pakistani girls, joined at the belly, as they were wheeled toward a Riyadh operating room.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nisar Ghani and his wife, Leena, with their daughters Fatima and Mishal in their guesthouse in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Corrupt Combatants Fight for Control of Lucrative Afghan Drug Trade
item.description: With no government efforts this year to eradicate Helmand Province’s poppy fields, millions of dollars are at stake — leaving dishonest officials and the Taliban to fight it out.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmers tended their opium crop last year in Helmand Province. Unlike previous years, there will be no serious efforts to eradicate the opium crop in Helmand because of Taliban advances and rampant corruption, with both sides battling over the drug trade.

item.title: U.S. Plans to Require Banks to Identify Owners of Shell Companies
item.description: The proposed rule is meant to close a loophole in the American banking system that allows secret financial maneuvers like the ones revealed in the Panama Papers.
item.dc:creator: LOUISE STORY

item.title: Panama Papers Tie More of China’s Elite to Secret Accounts
item.description: Leaked documents about offshore companies name family members of the country’s president, propaganda chief and vice premier.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Liu Yunshan, China’s propaganda chief, in Beijing in March. His daughter-in-law was once a shareholder and director of a company registered in the British Virgin Islands.

item.title: E.U. Migrant Proposals Aim to Overhaul Asylum Rules
item.description: The European Commission has suggested a mechanism to help countries overwhelmed by an influx of migrants.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Migrants on the Greek island of Chios on Wednesday.

item.title: Sidelined by Panama Papers Scandal, Iceland Premier Says He’s Not Quitting
item.description: Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson said he had stepped down amid the scandal only for an “unspecified” period.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson of Iceland at the residence of President Olafur Ragnar Grimsson in Reykjavik after a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: Model in Gucci Ad Is Deemed ‘Unhealthily Thin’ by British Regulator
item.description: The ruling by the Advertising Standards Authority fanned a perennial debate in the fashion industry about what constitutes underweight.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere: Signing Up Organ Donors in China Can Be an Uphill Battle
item.description: About 300,000 Chinese people require transplants each year, and voluntary donation, while growing, still falls far short of meeting that need.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: People wept as they paid their respects to deceased relatives in front of a monument bearing the names of organ donors ahead of the Qingming Festival on Monday, when Chinese honor their dead.

item.title: Cambodia to Bring Wild Tigers From Abroad in Fight Against Extinction
item.description: A small number of the animals will be taken to the Mondulkiri Protected Forest, the last place in the country one was seen.
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A tiger at the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center in the Cambodian province of Takeo last year.

item.title: Moshe Katsav, Jailed Ex-President of Israel, Loses Bid for Early Release
item.description: Mr. Katsav, who is serving a seven-year term for rape, had requested that his sentence be reduced by a third for good behavior.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Jerusalem Journal: Risk of Collapse at Jesus’ Tomb Unites Rival Christians
item.description: Three branches of Christianity are undertaking a $3.4 million renovation of the shrine holding Jesus’ tomb in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: The shrine holding the tomb of Jesus in Jerusalem’s Old City. The shrine, an unsteady 206-year-old structure held together by an iron cage, has become an uncomfortable symbol of Christian divisions.

item.title: North Korea May Roll Out Rocket System With Greater Reach, South Says
item.description: The weapon, which could be used as soon as this year, would expand the North’s ability to hit South Korean and American military forces in the South, the defense minister said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: North Korean surveillance cameras atop a steel tower peer into the South, near the border village of Panmunjom.

item.title: Sinosphere: Architect of China’s ‘Great Firewall’ Bumps Into It
item.description: During a presentation on digital security, the architect, Fang Binxing, was forced to use location-masking software to reach websites in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: People at an Internet bar in Beijing. China’s system of Internet controls, known as the Great Firewall, blocks access to certain foreign websites.
